question0: In a cartoon, an angel is perched on one shoulder and a devil is perched on the other shoulder of a character who needs to decide whether to give money to a homeless man or not. The devil says, "Don't give him anything, you'll make better use of the money than he will." The angel says, "Give him the money because he needs it more than you do." The character gives the homeless man half of his money. In a Freudian interpretation, the angel represents the character's
question1: Sodium bicarbonate ingestion improves middle distance running performance by:
option_1A: elevating the pH and buffering capacity of the extracellular fluid allowing a faster efflux of hydrogen ions from muscle.
option_1B: reducing the pH and buffering capacity of the extracellular fluid allowing a faster efflux of hydrogen ions from muscle.
option_1C: elevating the pH and buffering capacity of the extracellular fluid allowing a faster influx of hydrogen ions into muscle.
question2: A young lawyer worked late at her office one night. When she finally decided to go home, she headed to the elevator, got in, and pushed the button for the ground floor. The elevator went all the way to the ground floor, but then just stopped there. The doors did not open. The lawyer tried pushing each of the buttons in the elevator and tried to use the intercom in the elevator to call for help, but nothing on the elevator's control panel seemed to be functioning. The lawyer was afraid that she would be stuck in the elevator all night. She began pounding on the doors and yelling. She started to feel panicked, hyperventilated, lost consciousness, and fell to the floor of the elevator. As she fell, she struck her head on the elevator wall, causing a large bump and bruise on her head. She was unconscious in the elevator for about 30 minutes before a security guard tried to use the elevator and realized it wasn't working. The guard managed to force the doors open and found the lawyer. At that moment, the lawyer regained consciousness. An investigation revealed that the elevator stopped working because it had not been properly maintained. The owner of the building had canceled all service and maintenance work on the elevator in order to save money. If the lawyer sues the building owner for false imprisonment, she will most likely
option_2A: prevail, because she was confined in the elevator for an unreasonably long period of time.
option_2B: prevail, because she was injured during her confinement in the elevator.
option_2C: not prevail, because the building owner did not intentionally cause the lawyer to be confined.
option_2D: not prevail, because the lawyer was unconscious and unaware of what was happening for most of the confinement period.
question3: Statement 1 | The external direct product of cyclic groups is cyclic. Statement 2 | The external direct product of D_3 and D_4 is isomorphic to D_12.
question4: As of 2019, about what percentage of people from Russia says homosexuality should be accepted by society?
option_5A: the ability to control one's anger.
option_5B: a disposition to avoid extremes in feeling and action.
option_5D: the capacity to ascertain what God would desire.
question6:
Two processors, M-5 and M-7, implement the same instruction set. Processor M-5 uses a 5-stage pipeline and a clock cycle of 10 nanoseconds. Processor M-7 uses a 7-stage pipeline and a clock cycle of 7.5 nanoseconds. Which of the following is (are) true?
I. M-7’s pipeline has better maximum throughput than M-5’s pipeline.
II. The latency of a single instruction is shorter on M-7’s pipeline than on M-5’s pipeline.
III. Programs executing on M-7 will always run faster than programs executing on M-5.
question7: Which of the following points would Bayesians and frequentists disagree on?
option_7A: The use of a non-Gaussian noise model in probabilistic regression.
option_7B: The use of probabilistic modelling for regression.
option_7C: The use of prior distributions on the parameters in a probabilistic model.
option_7D: The use of class priors in Gaussian Discriminant Analysis.
question8: The dissolved salts in Earth's oceans are principally derived from
option_8D: the eruptions of undersea hot-spot volcanoes
question9: Which of the following would shift the aggregate demand curve to the left?
option_9B: Business firms expect lower sales in the future.
option_9C: Foreigners develop a preference for our products.
option_9D: Government increases its level of spending.

question0:

No task is more urgent than that of preserving peace. Without peace our independence means little. The rehabilitation and upbuilding of our countries will have little meaning. Our revolutions will not be allowed to run their course. What can we do? We can do much! We can inject the voice of reason into world affairs. We can mobilize all the spiritual, all the moral, all the political strength of Asia and Africa on the side of peace. Yes, we! We, the peoples of Asia and Africa, 1.4 billion strong.
Indonesian leader Sukarno, keynote address to the Bandung Conference, 1955
Like numerous other leaders in Africa, Asia, and the Middle East, Sukarno attempted, but did not completely succeed, in maintaining a neutral stance during
question1: Noncompetitive inhibition differs from uncompetitive inhibition in that a noncompetitive inhibitor binds to an allosteric site on the enzyme and prevents it from catalyzing a reaction, whereas uncompetitive inhibitors bind to the enzymesubstrate complex and prevent catalysis. Increasing the substrate concentration would have which of the following effects?
option_1A: Increasing impact of uncompetitive inhibitor and decreasing concentration of noncompetitive inhibitor
option_1B: Decreasing impact of uncompetitive inhibitor and increasing impact of noncompetitive inhibitor.
question2: What do meteorites reveal about the solar system?
option_2A: They reveal that the early solar system consisted mostly of hydrogen and helium gas.
option_2B: They reveal that meteorites are much older than the comets and planets.
option_2C: They reveal that the age of the solar system is approximately 4.6 billion years.
option_2D: They reveal that the solar system once contained 10 planets.

question7:
This question refers to the following information.
Clearly, no longer can a dictator count on East–West confrontation to stymie concerted United Nations action against aggression. A new partnership of nations has begun. And we stand today at a unique and extraordinary moment. The crisis in the Persian Gulf, as grave as it is, also offers a rare opportunity to move toward an historic period of cooperation. Out of these troubled times, our fifth objective—a new world order—can emerge; a new era, freer from the threat of terror, stronger in the pursuit of justice, and more secure in the quest for peace. An era in which the nations of the world, east and west, north and south, can prosper and live in harmony.
—President George Herbert Walker Bush, Speech to a Joint Session of Congress, September 11, 1990
President George Herbert Walker Bush's vision of a "new world order" was most directly made possible by
option_7B: President Ronald Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative.
option_7D: the end of the Cold War.
question8: To Kant, making a lying promise would be wrong because _____.
option_8A: lying to people can cause them harm
option_8C: you could not consistently will that everyone should make lying promises
question9: For which of these two scenarios does the main character (who uses I/me/my) do something clearly morally wrong? Scenario 1 | I taught my cat to use the park's sandbox as a litterbox. Scenario 2 | I followed my brother home from school.

question0: Suppose DVD players are a normal good and are exchanged in a competitive market. All else equal an increase in household income will
option_0A: increase the equilibrium quantity and increase the price.
option_0B: decrease the equilibrium quantity and increase the price.
option_0C: increase the equilibrium price but the change in quantity is ambiguous.
option_0D: decrease the equilibrium quantity and decrease the price.
question1: Within the context of sexual harassment, “quid pro quo” refers to:
option_1A: a situation in which an employee’s response to sexual demands impacts his/her job.
option_1B: "the creation of a ""hostile environment"" as a result of sexually offensive conduct. "
option_1C: "the judgment of a ""reasonable woman"" that an act is offensive. "
question2: What is meant by the term 'cyber-crime'?
option_2A: Any crime that uses computers to jeopardise or attempt to jeopardise national security
option_2B: The use of computer networks to commit financial or identity fraud
option_2D: Any crime that involves computers and networks
question3: When the production or consumption of a good creates a positive externality, it is deemed a market failure because at the market quantity
option_3A: the marginal social benefit exceeds the marginal social cost.
option_3B: the marginal social cost exceeds the marginal social benefit.
option_3C: society produces too much of the good.
option_3D: the private benefits from consuming the good exceed the social benefits.
question4:
This question refers to the following information.
"My little homestead in the city, which I recently insured for ￡2,000 would no doubt have shared the common fate, as the insurance companies will not make good that which is destroyed by the Queen's enemies. And although I have a farm of 50 acres close to the town, no doubt the crops and premises would have been destroyed. In fact, this has already partly been the case, and I am now suing the Government for damages done by a contingent of 1,500 natives that have recently encamped not many hundred yards from the place, who have done much damage all around."
Letter from a British citizen to his sister during the Anglo-Zulu War, South Africa, 1879
Which of the following reasons explains why European citizens moved in large numbers to Zulu lands in 1867?
option_4A: The British crown offered incentives to those who would establish homesteads in the unsettled lands of South Africa.
option_4B: The Zulu created attractive trade ports along the Indian Ocean.
option_4C: The Berlin Conference clarified boundaries, thus making it logistically sound for Europeans to move to the African colonies.
option_4D: A diamond rush ensued following the discovery of diamonds on Zulu lands.
question5:
This question refers to the following information.
"The Chinese are all infidels: they worship images, and burn their dead just like the [Hindus]. The King of China is a Tartar, and one of the descendants of [Ghenghis] Khan…In all the Chinese provinces, there is a town for the [Muslims], and in this they reside. They also have cells, colleges, and mosques, and are made much of by the Kings of China…
When we approached this city [of Hangzhou] we were met by its judge, the [elders] of Islamism, and the great merchants. The [Muslims] are exceedingly numerous here. This whole city is surrounded by a wall: each of the six [districts of Hangzhou] is also surrounded by a wall. In the first reside the guards, with their commander. I was told that, in the muster-rolls, these amount to twelve thousand…In the second division are the Jews, Christians, and the Turks who worship the sun: these are numerous, their number is not known: and theirs is the most beautiful city. Their streets are well disposed, and their great men are exceedingly wealthy. There are in the city a great number of [Muslims], with some of whom I resided for fifteen days; and was treated most [honorably]…"
Ibn Battuta, Voyages, 1332–1346 C.E.
Which of the following conclusions about the period 600 C.E.–1450 C.E. is most directly supported by the passage?
option_5B: New religious traditions overturned prior lasting religious beliefs.
option_5C: The empires of steppe nomads united trade links across Eurasia.
option_5D: Technological developments spread across trade routes.
question6: For which of these two scenarios does the main character (who uses I/me/my) do something clearly morally wrong? Scenario 1 | I invited my date to the lighthouse for a romantic evening. Scenario 2 | I ambushed my mother with a difficult question.
question7: Which of the following best describes the definition of poverty used by the United States government?
option_7A: It specifies the poverty line at a level set in the 1960s and adjusted since to reflect inflation.
option_7B: It includes the value of government services, such as Medicaid or public housing, when setting the poverty line.
option_7C: It is based on the concept of relative deprivation, and the poverty line changes as the distribution of income changes.
option_7D: It is based on the concept of lifestyle, and the poverty line varies according to the needs of the individual.
question8: In what situation are closed pouches applied?
option_8A: The patient has a semi-formed or liquid output.
question9: Detection of a just-noticeable difference (JND) depends on the
option_9A: presence of a "no stimulus" control and the sensitivity of the signal-detection equipment
option_9B: initial determination of the absolute threshold and the variation of the difference threshold
option_9C: frequency of the existing stimulus and the presence of one or more sensory modalities
option_9D: intensity of the new stimulus and that of the stimulus already present

question0: Which statement describes an idea from utilitarianism?
option_0A: What is right and what is wrong are predetermined.
option_0B: People should be treated as an end, not a means to an end.
option_0C: The greatest good for the greatest number.
option_0D: Those better off should give to people who are not as well off.
question1:
This question refers to the following information.
Source 1:
"Moreover, Sir, in our Kingdoms there is another great inconvenience which is of little service to God, and this is that many of our people, keenly desirous as they are of the wares and things of your Kingdoms, which are brought here by your people, and in order to satisfy their voracious appetite, seize many of our people, freed and exempt men, and very often it happens that they kidnap even noblemen and our relatives, and take them to be sold to the white men who are in our kingdoms."
Letter from King Afonso I of Kongo to King John III of Portugal, 1526
Source 2:
"This expedition has cost us much: it would be unreasonable to send it home with empty hands. Although our [principal] wish is to serve God and the pleasure of the king of Kongo, none the less you will make him understand—as though speaking in our name—what he should do to fill the ships, whether with slaves, or copper, or ivory."
Instructions from King Manuel of Portugal to his envoy in Kongo, 1512
The two letters best support which of the following conclusions?
option_1A: Diplomatic relations between Portugal and Kongo were often cordial.
option_1B: Kongolese noblemen were frequently taken as slaves by the Portuguese.
option_1C: Trade between Portugal and Kongo was highly regulated.
option_1D: Trade between Portugal and Kongo was brisk with both parties.
question2: A state has passed a law that provides that only residents of the state who are citizens of the United States can own agricultural land in the state. A out- of-state farmer who is a U. S. citizen has contracted, subsequent to the aforementioned law, to purchase a farm from a landowner, which is located in the state. The landowner, who is a resident of the state, has been informed by his attorney that his sales agreement with the farmer is null and void under state law. Which of the following is the best constitutional argument to contest the validity of the state statute?
option_2A: The contract clause prohibition against a state from enacting any law that will impair the obligation of contracts.
option_2B: The privileges and immunities clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
option_2C: The privileges and immunities clause under Article IV, Section 2.
option_2D: The national property power provision under Article IV, Section 3.

option_6B: The predecessor auditor’s understanding of the reasons for the change of auditors

question9: A pregnant woman was sitting on her front porch watching her husband mow the lawn. A friend of the woman had known the woman for years and knew that she was an easily excitable person. The friend also hated the woman's husband. Knowing that the woman was present, the friend drew a pistol and threatened to kill the husband. The woman suffered severe emotional distress as a result of witnessing this incident and soon afterward had a miscarriage. In an action by the woman against the friend for mental anguish resulting in her miscarriage, the woman will
option_9A: lose, because the friend did not intend for the woman to suffer a miscarriage.
option_9B: lose, because the friend's actions were directed against the husband, not the woman.
option_9C: win, because it was highly probable that the friend's extreme and outrageous conduct would cause emotional distress to the woman.
option_9D: win, because she is the husband's wife.

question0: A deed executed by a woman in 2001 conveyed a tract of land for a consideration of one dollar, receipt of which was acknowledged, "to my friend for life, but if liquor is ever sold on the tract of land, then to my cousin and his heirs, and if for any reason the interest hereby conveyed to my cousin is not valid, then I reserve the right to re-enter the tract of land and take back my property. " In 2004, the friend died intestate before the wheat he had planted could be harvested. Who is entitled to the proceeds of the crop?
option_0D: Divided equally between the friend's heirs and the woman.

option_1A: Evolution is a gradual process that occurs over a long period of time.

question4: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of two 12-hour episodes of dizziness over the past 3 months. During episodes, she experiences the acute onset of rotatory vertigo and imbalance, decreased hearing, tinnitus, a sense of fullness of the right ear, and vomiting. Examination shows a mild hearing loss of the right ear. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
question6: You have been hired as a research assistant for a study that will compare two brief treatments for Social Phobia. The procedures and methods used in the study are ethically sound; however, your supervisor is not informing participants that they may withdraw from the study at any time if they desire to do so. Your best course of action would be to:
option_6B: inform the participants yourself of their right to withdraw.
option_6C: discuss the possible ethical violation with the supervisor.
option_6D: do nothing since this is an acceptable practice.
question7: Which of the following vitamins provides the cofactor for hydroxylation reactions in collagen synthesis?
question8: A city sent a certified notice by U.S. mail to a homeowner telling the owner that the property was listed for a foreclosure sale for failure to pay real estate property taxes. The post office quickly returned the notice to the city as being "unclaimed." The city decided that the notice was sufficient, and sold the property. The owner had been out of the country and did not claim his certified mail. When he found out he sued the city on the basis that there was insufficient notice. Will the owner succeed in having the foreclosure declared void by the court?
option_8A: No, because the sending of certified notice to the property's address was reasonably calculated to reach him, which satisfies due process concerns.
option_8B: No, because the owner knew that he wasn't paying his taxes and that constituted de facto notice that that his property was subject to governmental taking.
option_8C: Yes, because in most circumstances an "unclaimed" notification is insufficient to satisfy the demands of due process.
option_8D: No, because the city had a right to expect that an owner will leave his property in the hands of someone who will notify him if his interest is in jeopardy.
